intro: Acacia desertorum var. desertorum, commonly known as the desert acacia, is a shrub native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its slender, branching stems and small, compound leaves that reduce water loss in hot, dry environments. The plant produces yellow flowers in late spring, which are clustered in spherical inflorescences. Its root system is deep and extensive, allowing it to access groundwater in nutrient-poor soils. This species is well adapted to harsh desert conditions and plays a role in stabilizing sandy soils.

It is commonly found in the arid and semi-arid regions of the state, particularly in the Nullarbor Plain and surrounding areas. This plant thrives in sandy soils and is well adapted to the harsh, dry conditions of the region. It is often seen growing along roadsides and in open habitats. Its distribution is limited to the southern and central parts of Western Australia.
